text:
JILL FADULE: Hello. Greetings from Klarman Hall
at Harvard Business School.

I'm Jill Fadule. I'm the Director of Joint
Degree Programs here at Harvard. I'm also a member
of the admissions

board for both the MBA program
and the MS/MBA program. We're really excited to get
started in just a moment.

We're going to kick off by
hearing from our HBS faculty co-chair of the program,
Professor Tom Eisenmann.

And he's going to tell you a
little bit about the vision for the program. Then we're going
to be joined by two

members of the inaugural
cohort of the MS/MBA program. And they're going to
share with you some

of the distinctive features
of the program and the reasons why they're excited about it. Then I will talk with you
about our admissions criteria

and the admissions process. But please keep in mind, this
program is all about you.

We're here to answer
your questions and bring the program
to life for you. So ask away, and we'll respond.

Now I'd like to ask
each of our speakers to please introduce themselves.

TOM EISENMANN: Hi,
I'm Tom Eisenmann. I'm faculty chair of the MS/MBA.

My counterpart from the
engineering school, Rob Howe, is a professor of robotics. I'm also faculty chair
of the Rock Center

for Entrepreneurship
at HBS, which works with alumni
and students on extra-curricular programming.

I teach a core course in the
MS/MBA, Technology Venture Immersion, and a pretty broad
range of technology courses

beyond that in the MBA program. EMILY BATT: Hi, I'm Emily Batt. I'm an inaugural member
of the MS/MBA cohorts.

And I'm also a proud member
of Section G here at HBS. Prior to HBS, I got
my degree in physics

at Northeastern University. I spent about five years as
a mechanical design engineer at Fikst Product Development
and then about three at KAYAK

in product management. I spent the summer at
a seed stage startup called Paperless
Parts here in Boston.

ANKITH HARATHI: Hi,
my name is Ankith. I'm also a member of
the inaugural MS/MBA cohort along with Emily.

I graduated from
Cornell with a degree in mechanical engineering. And prior to HBS, I
was working in eSports,

or competitive video gaming,
at a startup company. And at HBS, I'm a proud
member of Section A.

TOM EISENMANN: So thanks
for tuning in, everybody. As Jill said, we wanted
to start by giving you

an overview of the program. So our objective is to train
future leaders of technology

ventures. The way we do that is with
an emphasis on building

foundations of
general management through a heavy
emphasis on design. And I'll come back to that.

And then lastly, by building
capabilities and understanding around engineering.

So a central element
of the program-- and really, the part that
joins the engineering school

and the business school-- is the emphasis on design. And we think of
design very broadly. Design, of course, of
products, but also you

design your business models and
you design your organizations. And the same structured approach
and disciplined approach

to thinking about design
options and figuring out whether there are good options
runs all through the program.

We emphasize design through-- we'll talk more about
the curriculum later-- but we have five core
courses, each of which

emphasizes different
aspects of design. Program, as Jill
said, is brand new.

The first cohort
started in August and will graduate in 2020. The program takes two years,
essentially 21 months.

So the students start in
August and then finish in May of the second year.

And as you'll hear in a few
minutes, a lot of structure, but also a lot of flexibility,
especially in the second year

of the program. With that background, I want
to ask Emily and Ankith,

why did you pursue an MS/MBA? EMILY BATT: Yeah, yeah. Well, I've always been
excited about technology

and its capability to
really affect broad change. But what I loved about
the MS/MBA program

was that you could also take
two years to really focus on your own leadership
style and how you can maximize that change,
leveraging your own strengths.

And I didn't want to abandon
the technical rigor that I had come to love in my career. So having the chance to pursue
both the engineering curriculum

and the business curriculum
was really important to me. ANKITH HARATHI: For
me, I always knew

I was interested in
entrepreneurship or tech ventures, coming from
a startup as well. And so I viewed going
to business school,

going to HBS, as
a sort of a hedge, especially with
the MS/MBA program, to be able to do very
risky things maybe

later after the
program, like creating multiple different startups
if one inevitably fails. But also the experience
of being the first cohort

of this new program and getting
to bond with 30 individuals prior to the start of
the actual MBA program

and having a kind of
smaller group of people that are your family before you
get thrown into 1,000 people

in the RC year-- TOM EISENMANN: "RC" is the
first year of the MBA program. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah. RC, yes. The required curriculum. TOM EISENMANN:
Required curriculum.

ANKITH HARATHI: Yup. And so, yes, being with so many
like-minded individuals who all come from technical
backgrounds who

are, a lot of them, interested
in entrepreneurship as well, was just a great opportunity.

TOM EISENMANN: Did either
of you worry about-- so this is brand new-- you took a risk with a
program that had never

been delivered before. How did you think about that? EMILY BATT: Yeah, I mean I
think that Harvard has always

had an incredible amount of
resources for entrepreneurship and technical ventures. But what I saw on campus
was a real excitement

for this new program and the
chance to be a part of that. I think the excitement
was contagious. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah,
I think it's something

that just, along
those same lines, speaking to alumni advisors or
people in industry who maybe weren't even affiliated
with HBS, when I told them

I was considering
this program they were incredibly excited, saying
if this had existed either when they were going
to business school

or maybe they never even
went to business school, but they said that this is
a problem that they would be very interested in having done.

And so that just got me very
excited about this, really, combination of engineering and
business at this sort of level.

TOM EISENMANN: Yeah. Well, we're excited, too. So let's give the
audience a sense for what the program's
actually about.

So I'll give that
overview-- sort of go step by step through the two years.

And then, Ankith and Emily,
I'll come back to you. And you've experienced
already the first few months.

And so you can comment
on what it was like and what you learned
and on what you

think about what's coming next. So the program starts in
August of the first year.

And there are 29 students
in the first cohort.

So they all meet together for
2 and 1/2 weeks in August.

And it's an engineering course
called "Systems Engineering." The two of you will
describe it in a few minutes

far better than I will. EMILY BATT: [CHUCKLES] TOM EISENMANN: But
we thought it was very important for the
cohort to bond as a group.

And that's a great way
to do it, as Ankith said, before everybody enters the
first year of the MBA program.

So after that,
after that 2 and 1/2 week Systems Engineering
course, the MS/MBAs

are dispersed to
the 10 MBA sections. So MBAs are divided into 10
sections of about 90 apiece.

And so about three MS/MBAs ended
up in each of those sections. And they, in those sections, do
the entire required curriculum.

It's just what you'd
expect in an MBA program-- a required course on
marketing, on finance,

on organizational
behavior, leadership, accounting strategy,
entrepreneurship, and so forth.

Along the way, every few
weeks, we bring the group back together for a seminar,
where we bring in typically

outside speakers. So we can talk about a few
of those that we've done. For example, we brought in the
head of Harvard University's

Office of Technology
Development, the technology licensing office, to talk to the
students about the work they do

and opportunities
for the MS/MBAs to work on those
types of projects.

So one of the ways
we can confer-- I should have said earlier
that the program confers two degrees--

a Master of Science in
Engineering Sciences and MBA in the two years. It's very important. And the way we could fit
all that in in two years

is we've stuck three extra
courses-- one in the August course I described,
but then at Harvard

we've got a long
break essentially from the middle of December
to almost the end of January.

And we're able to stick
two more courses in there. In the first year, of the course
is called Technology Venture
Immersion. Two weeks long. It has two parts. Part 1 is all about prototyping.

So the students
will, in teams, build a device that uses
sensors to actuate motors

and maybe will
follow a laser around or something with Arduinos and
laser cutters and 3D printers.

Emily's smiling because
she did this for a living for a long time. EMILY BATT: All the good stuff. [LAUGHS] TOM EISENMANN: But the idea
is to build some basic skills

around prototyping and also
the skills on the team that has to integrate
hardware, software,

and electronic components. That's part 1. Part 2, again, in different
teams-- small teams--

students will take an idea
for a technology venture and move it as far as
they can, basically, from glimmer in their eye,
all the way to a pitch deck

that they, at the
end of that week, will present to a panel that
includes investors, venture

capitalists, seasoned
entrepreneurs, and faculty members. So each day along the way in
Technology Venture Immersion,

there'll be classes
in the morning that emphasize, through
exercises and cases and so forth, some
aspect of skills

that are really important
in launching an early stage technology venture-- so
marketing, assembling the team,

fundraising, and so forth. And in the afternoon, the
teams will go into studio. And they'll take what they
learned in the morning

and push their venture
forward, essentially building toward this pitch at
the end of the week. Then the winter and
spring of the first year

is back to the required
curriculum of the MBA program. Summer is off.

We think a lot of people
will work on a startup idea or they'll go to internships
and technology companies.

And then a second year is
where a lot of flexibility comes to play. So there are some core
courses, required courses

for the program. In the fall, there's of course
called Integrated Design, which takes the design skills and
moves them to the next level.

And there's a
capstone, as in a lot of master's-level
engineering programs-- essentially a thesis project
where, again, in teams,

teams will take a product
concept and move it to launch, starting in January and then
continuing in the spring

semester. So in total, the MS/MBAs
will experience three or four

intense design
cycles where they go from idea to prototype
and product launch

over and over again, picking
up new skills each time. Last component of the
program is electives.

So the students will take four
MBA electives from a broad

range-- we offer more than 100
elective courses in the second year of the MBA program-- and then, likewise, will choose
three technical engineering

courses from the broad set
of courses offered at SEAS. So that's the program.

Then graduation, and then
off to do amazing things out in the world of technology.

So, Ankith and Emily,
you've experienced already several parts of this.

So can you talk a little bit
about what systems engineering did and what it was like. EMILY BATT: Yeah, yeah. Happy to talk about
the August course.

So in August, we spent
about three weeks in Systems Engineering. The first half was really
focused on statistics.

So it was kind of a crash course
in everything you need to know. The second half was about
controls and systems design.

And then for the
final component, we combined those two modules
to try to model a business

plan for a startup. So you could pick any
startup you wanted-- either one that exists
or your own idea--

and use statistics
and control systems to understand the risks
that business is facing

and what sort of growth it
could anticipate over time. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah. And what was really
unique about that course,

compared to courses that at
least I took in undergrad, were the statistics
and the actual control system was very theoretical
with problem sets.

But then the actual
application-- and it wasn't just an
application in a problem, but modeling an actual
company that exists--

I know a bunch of groups
did Spotify, Blue Apron. My group actually focused
on one of my startup ideas. And it was interesting
to actually

be able to understand
our business model, but also our operating
model's sensitivity to certain parameters
to figure out

at what scale do we need to
grow this business to actually be financially viable or at
scale for venture capitalists?

And so that's something
that I had never experienced before in terms
of just vetting startup ideas or concepts that you have.

And it was just a
real, true application of these technical skills in
an entrepreneurial environment.

JILL FADULE: We
got a question that came in asking about
relationships with faculty.

What are the relationships
with the faculty like? EMILY BATT: Yeah. Well, I think because
the cohort is so small,

you have really incredible
access to faculty. You're with them every day in
August before the RC starts.

And you have the ability
to build relationships beyond the classroom. So for advice with
your startup or--

actually career
advice, in general-- I think the access to
faculty is unparalleled. ANKITH HARATHI:
Yeah, definitely.

I think for being the
first cohort, but then also the first few
cohorts I go through, there is actually just
such genuine excitement

about this program. All the faculty,
even the MBA faculty who aren't even directly
involved in the program,

are excited to hear
that this is happening and are interested
to meet with you and understand what
you're working on

or what are you hoping to
get out of the program. And so, like Emily said, you can
actually approach any faculty.

A lot of the time, they
approach you and ask you how the MS/MBA is doing. And they're just excited to
hear about what we as a cohort

are up to. JILL FADULE: Great. There was another question
about intellectual property. And I think maybe Tom
could be helpful here

because you've had many
students deal with some of that. But you're working
in these teams. And you're developing
great ideas.

And how do we think
about who owns that intellectual property? TOM EISENMANN: Yeah. So there are two
questions that folks

have to think about there. One is, does the university
have any ownership of what

the teams are working on? And the second is, how
do the team members sort out who owns what?

And with respect
to the university, as is the case
across everything we

do at Harvard, unless the idea
makes heavy use of resources

in, for example, the
Harvard laboratories, the assumption is the
students own the IP.

And our colleagues
in engineering have got a lot of
experience figuring out what "heavy use" means.

But in most cases, I think,
the kinds of projects-- well, in some cases, it's
already clear that the MS/MBAs

for the project work they'll do
in January in the Tech Venture Immersion course, we've
shared with them-- we had--

my colleague Rob
Howe brought in-- spoke to his counterparts in
various labs and asked them,

do you have any
inventions that are ready for
commercialization, where no one's done the basic
work of figuring out

what the market looks like? And we had a science
fair, basically. And project fair. EMILY BATT: (CHUCKLING) Yup.

TOM EISENMANN: And so
those are all examples of ideas that were moved
along with heavy involvement

of Harvard labs and grants from,
say, the National Institutes of Health or NSF or so forth.

So in that case, it
would've been sorted out with the university's
technology licensing office, Office of Technology
Development, who owns what.

And if the venture
moves forward, then the entrepreneurs moving it
forward, including the MS/MBAs

would license the technology
from the University. Far more typically the case
when our MBAs launch programs.

It's not done with technologies
coming out of labs. And then it's simple
and straightforward.

The student entrepreneurs
own the idea. It's up to them, though, then
to sort out who on the team

is going to take
the idea forward. And if they're going
to launch a business,

how are they going to divide
the equity in that business. Is that consistent with what
you've heard and learned? ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah.

EMILY BATT: Yeah, definitely. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah. JILL FADULE: There
was a question about how you've experienced
the early days of the program?

And were there any
things confirmed about your expectations
or any surprises along the way
about what you were

expecting from the program? ANKITH HARATHI: Sure. So I think one of the biggest
questions I had coming in,

which my expectations were-- my experience would probably
be very bifurcated, was how a part of the
community that I would

feel at HBS and also
at SEAS in terms of, they're two different schools. Physically, they're
across the river.

But that's actually changing as
SEAS moves campuses-- actually in 2020, the year we
graduate-- to just

be right across the
street from HBS. And I was actually very
pleasantly surprised. I think that the way that
the program is structured,

you definitely get the
core HBS experience. You get to be part
of your section. You're socializing
with your section

as often as you want to. And but you also get to be part
of SEAS really well, just not

in the MS/MBA cohort, but
the School of Engineering we're on all of their
listserves in terms of the graduate students.

We have regular meetups
in terms of happy hours or in terms of just scientific
talks or discussions.

And so it's a really
unique position that you get to take
within the university, of being integral to
both these communities

and feeling like you're
part of everything and you're not compromising
anywhere on your experience. EMILY BATT: Yeah.

TOM EISENMANN: I
want to keep going. So you must have
had expectations

for what the case
method would be like and how hard you'd work
in the MBA program? So how's that all going?

EMILY BATT: [LAUGHING]
Yeah, that's been surprising to me, actually. I'm loving the business classes
way more than I expected.

It's just so different
from anything I've experienced before. The case method absolutely is
pushing at my comfort zone.

I think sometimes
as a scientist, my comfort zone is to
be in observational mode

and collect data for a long
time before making a decision. But what the case
method does is really encourages you to have a lot
of conviction in what you're

presenting, but also to
remain open to having that view challenged
and to really engage in an active dialogue.

And even in the few weeks
that we've been here, I've noticed the way that I
converse in my everyday life has changed.

And I think that's one
element of transformation I didn't expect to
experience so quickly.

ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah. For me, what's been very
surprising about the actual HBS curriculum is
finance is actually

one of my favorite classes,
in that I learn the most. And coming into this
program, I did not

expect that to be the case. But it's interesting
how these concepts, they're taught in
such a way that you're engaged with the material.

And you're not just
learning financial equations of solving, again, problems. But rather, these are
companies that we're

dealing with
situations in terms of, maybe it was venture funding
for the startup company. And so how you
actually get funding,

or do you choose to get funding? Do you raise debt? Do you bootstrap? All of these are decisions
that I very well may have

to make in the future and
these people actually, that we're reading
about, did make. And so learning of what's
happened in the past

and how they overcame
these obstacles I think is invaluable to moving
forward with your own venture

or whatever you want to do. TOM EISENMANN: May I ask
one more about surprises? So I think in a lot of
technology companies,

the engineers in particular
have strong views about what business people are like
and what MBAs are like.

And so you're surrounded
for the first year by MBAs.

Are they like what you expected? EMILY BATT: [LAUGHS] I mean,
I think the thing about HBS is that you get people from
every background imaginable.

Just being in the room
with my section every day, I'm blown away with what
people bring to the table.

So I think that, no, I didn't
really know what to expect. I thought I might be
a fish out of water.

But what I feel is that I'm
being challenged every day and I'm learning every day and
I'm loving every minute of it.

So in a way, I think that
was surprising to me. But I don't know. I don't think you can
generalize the type

in the way that some people-- TOM EISENMANN: Yeah. You worked in a company started
by two Harvard MBAs, so. EMILY BATT: [LAUGHS] ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah.

TOM EISENMANN: You had
an advantage coming in. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah. I mean, I definitely didn't
have any negative preconceptions prior at HBS.

But I think the general
feeling of engineers working in either the tech companies
is that the MBAs are

kind of the business people. They don't really
understand what you're doing or what you're building. And they kind of tell you
what to do without actually

doing it themselves. And I think coming here-- I actually didn't believe it to
come in-- but I think even just

seeing the people
in the classroom, there are actually so many
people interested in technology here. And it's not only technical
people in the MS/MBA

who are very
entrepreneurially focused. Like if you go to
i-lab, which is one of the great resources
Harvard has for building

startups, it's just
a working space that anybody can work
on their startup idea, there's so many people that are
always working on something.

And it's actually
a great position for the MS/MBAs, in that
a lot of people in the MBA are actually trying
to build things.

And they're always
looking for help or advice from people who have the
technical skills, whether it's coding or 3D printing or
designing with CAD software.

And so they are actually
just as entrepreneurially minded or technology-focused
as we are.

So it's great to work with them. JILL FADULE: [CHUCKLES] A question came in
about the advantage

of doing the joint
MBA with the MS or doing a standalone
MS and a standalone MBA.

What do you think
are the advantages for doing the joint degree? EMILY BATT: Yeah.

Well, I would say
this program is new. So we don't know exactly how it
will play out in the long run.

But for me, I was
just excited to be able to spend my time
in business classes

and engineering classes. And being able to do it
on the two-year timeline was really appealing
to me because I'm

eager to get out there and work
and build what I want to build. And having it be the same time
footprint as the normal MBA

experience was really appealing. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah. I think the timeline
is a huge part.

A lot of the people I
talked to before getting admitted into the
HBS MS/MBA program

were saying, if you're
interested in entrepreneurship, you could just go out and do it. There's no impetus or reason to
actually go to an MBA program.

The MS/MBA really changes that. But then also, it's only
a two-year investment versus four years if you want
to do both masters separately,

or even three years
at other programs. And I think that there's
a huge opportunity cost to whenever you go back
to school for graduate studies.

And it's, what else
could you be doing? And I think that by
crafting this program in such a deliberate way
for just the two years,

you get so much value
out of the two years. You're not taking up
extra time financially. It's only two years of
school versus three or four

years of school. And I think that
you really maximize what you get out of
just two years as opposed to doing the
program separately.

TOM EISENMANN: Yeah, so the
team that designed the program, we had a blank sheet
of paper at the start.

We could have done
whatever we wanted, including a master's that
was neither an MS nor an MBA.

And we considered that
possibility as possibly a way to get it done in 18 months
or a year or two years.

But we knew we wanted to train
future leaders of technology ventures who need to know about
both technology and business.

And so I didn't know
how much of the business you'd need to put into the
program at the beginning.

And I had a hypothesis,
maybe we could cut out half of the first year of the MBA.

And I went session by session
through the first year of the MBA and said,
nope, got to keep that.

Nope, yup, you need
the accounting. You need the finance. You need the marketing. You need the leadership. And came to the conclusion
that you pretty much

have to have the whole thing. So we feel very strongly
that the MS and the MBA

belong together, but it
ought to be a full MBA. JILL FADULE: We have a
fun question that came in.

I hope we have time for this one
because it's, what do you like to do outside of the classroom? EMILY BATT: [LAUGHS] ANKITH HARATHI: Hmm.

TOM EISENMANN: Uh-huh. EMILY BATT: [CONTINUES LAUGHING]
Time outside of the classroom is very limited these days. [LAUGHS] ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah.

EMILY BATT: So I mean,
I think that one thing I love talking about is
the art scene in Boston.

When I was working, it
was really important to me that I stay involved in kind
of creative outlets outside of engineering.

And that's something
I love to do. So, yeah. Play guitar badly. TOM EISENMANN: What kind of art? EMILY BATT: Oh, I play
guitar really badly.

TOM EISENMANN: No, what
of art was the art scene? EMILY BATT: Oh, oh. Well, I see a lot of live music.

I love the Gardner
Museum, the ICA. So being in Boston at
Harvard, all of that

is right at your fingertips. And that's something I
would encourage everyone to check out. ANKITH HARATHI: Mine's not
as a creative of an answer.

[LAUGHTER] So actually, I
co-founded a company with another MS/MBA
student, John Keck. And so a lot of the time
that we're not in class,

we're choosing to work
on a startup company. And interestingly, at
that startup company, both of us were
mechanical engineers--

John and I. But
that startup company is in artificial intelligence,
like machine learning and time management. And so we're both learning
that skill set over time.

He has more experience
at it than I do. But I think that's
actually one of the ways I've kind of naturally
kind of developed

my skills through the program is
taking on these new skill sets that I haven't previously had,
and then also looking forward

to the elective courses
we take next year in terms of machine learning and neural
networks and stuff like that.

Those are the courses
I'm eyeing next year, not only for its applicability to
what I'm currently working on,

but just a general
interest and not having done that in undergrad. JILL FADULE: Great.

TOM EISENMANN: Do you work
in New York or Boston? ANKITH HARATHI: Boston, local. TOM EISENMANN: Boston. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah. TOM EISENMANN: So
both of you in Boston. ANKITH HARATHI: Yeah.

JILL FADULE: So we're
getting some questions about admissions. And so I think I might
take a quick minute to talk a little bit about
that before we go back

to the questions for students
and our faculty chair. So you've heard these wonderful
things about the program.

I think you're probably
hoping to join us. And I want to tell
you what we're looking for for the next
cohort of MS/MBA students.

First off, we really
want people who aspire to lead technology ventures. Second, we'd like
people who have

undergraduate degrees
in engineering, computer science, or
related technical fields.

Third, we want people who
have at least two years of full-time work
experience, ideally

in designing and
developing new products. Technology-intensive
products would be great.

And the last thing is, that
people admitted to the MS/MBA have to satisfy all of the
requirements of the MBA

program. And the criteria for the
MBA program are threefold. We want people who
have demonstrated

a habit of leadership, who
have strong analytical aptitude and a real appetite to
do that kind of work,

as well as people
who are involved in the communities around them. So that's what
we're looking for.

We're thrilled with
the 29 students that are part of this cohort
with Ankith and Emily,

because they are fabulous
people, fabulous students, and they come from very diverse
professional work backgrounds.

Yes, we have several from giant
tech companies like Microsoft, Apple, Google, Amazon.

We also have people
from big companies that might not be giants
quite yet, like Uber or SpaceX

or Tesla or KAYAK, like Emily. And then we have people from
traditional manufacturing

companies like GE,
Procter & Gamble, Eaton.

And then we have several
of their classmates who are very, very interested in
life sciences and health care.

We have a few with
military backgrounds. We have a few with
cybersecurity backgrounds.

We have nine people who,
like Ankith and Emily, have startup experience already.

And we have two people who
came into the program already being co-founders. So you can see we welcome people
from a variety of backgrounds.

And we really think
that's important to making the cohort work so well,
is that we have people from such different backgrounds.

The process to apply to
this program is as follows.

You need to be admitted
to both the MBA program and the Master of
Science and Engineering

program. But the application is
being hosted at HBS.

So all the elements
to your application will be hosted by HBS,
but there will be two

independent decisions made-- one by the MBA
admissions board and one by the MS/MBA committee.

What's required to apply for
the MBA are a few things. There are some application
forms that we get

to know a little bit about you. You send us your resume. We get two letters
of recommendation.

You respond to our essay prompt. We get your undergraduate
transcripts. We get transcripts
from any graduate work

you may have done. We get your standardized
test scores. We take either the
GMAT or the GRE.

We're completely indifferent
as to which one you send us. And if your undergraduate
study was at a school

where English was not
the primary language of instruction,
then you also need to submit a proficiency test,
an English proficiency test,

like the TOEFL. So that's what is required
for the MBA program.

For the MS/MBA program, we look
at all of those same things, plus we get one additional
supplemental essay addressing

your interest in this program. And if you're invited to
come for an interview, you will then be asked to
submit one additional letter

of recommendation. And that third letter
of recommendation should come from somebody
who can speak specifically

to your technical capabilities. Now if you want to join
us in August of 2019

and be part of the second-ever
cohort of MS/MBA students, you would apply by January 4.

So hopefully that gets at some
of the questions that have been coming in on admissions. And we'll turn to see
what's coming down the pike.

as we call them here. And the question was,
are there scholarships? And yes, there are.

The way that we do financial
aid for this program is we host the financial
aid process also at HBS.

And it happens after you gain
admission to the program. So you don't need to
worry about it now.

And we have a need-blind
admissions process. So we're not worrying
about anything

to do with money when we're
reading your application. And we choose people
based on their merits.

And then when we start
the financial aid process soon after you get
admitted, you send

us all of your information. You fill out the forms. And we determine, based on your
demonstrated financial need,

whether or not you
qualify for fellowship. And for us, "fellowship"
means it's money

that we're giving you that
you don't have to pay back. And about 60% of
the cohort of 29

qualified for
need-based fellowship. And on average, the fellowship
size is about $40,000

each year. So $80,000 total. So yes, we do provide that
kind of financial assistance.
